trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to get started using Azure Blob storage after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in an ASP.NET app by using the Visual Studio **Add Connected Services** dialog box.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to get started using Azure Blob storage after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in an ASP.NET app by using the Visual Studio **Add Connected Services** dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The article shows you how to create blob containers and perform other common tasks such as uploading, listing, downloading, and deleting blobs.
trans-unit.target: The article shows you how to create blob containers and perform other common tasks such as uploading, listing, downloading, and deleting blobs.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C\# and
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C\# and

trans-unit.source: use the [Azure Storage Client Library for .NET](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn261237.aspx).
trans-unit.target: use the [Azure Storage Client Library for .NET](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn261237.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For more general information about using Azure Blob storage, see [How to use Blob storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md).
trans-unit.target: For more general information about using Azure Blob storage, see [How to use Blob storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information about ASP.NET projects, see [ASP.NET](http://www.asp.net).
trans-unit.target: For more information about ASP.NET projects, see [ASP.NET](http://www.asp.net).

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: A single blob can be any size.
trans-unit.target: A single blob can be any size.

trans-unit.source: Blobs can be things like images, audio and video files, raw data, and document files.
trans-unit.target: Blobs can be things like images, audio and video files, raw data, and document files.

trans-unit.source: Just as files live in folders, storage blobs live in containers.
trans-unit.target: Just as files live in folders, storage blobs live in containers.

trans-unit.source: After you have created a storage account, you create one or more containers in the storage.
trans-unit.target: After you have created a storage account, you create one or more containers in the storage.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a storage called “Scrapbook,” you can create blob containers in the storage called “images” to store pictures and another called “audio” to store audio files.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a storage called “Scrapbook,” you can create blob containers in the storage called “images” to store pictures and another called “audio” to store audio files.

trans-unit.source: After you create the containers, you can upload individual blob files to them.
trans-unit.target: After you create the containers, you can upload individual blob files to them.

trans-unit.source: Access blob containers in code
trans-unit.target: Access blob containers in code

trans-unit.source: To programmatically access blobs in ASP.NET projects, you need to add the following items, if they're not already present.
trans-unit.target: To programmatically access blobs in ASP.NET projects, you need to add the following items, if they're not already present.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C# file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C# file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Get a `CloudStorageAccount` object that represents your storage account information.
trans-unit.target: Get a `CloudStorageAccount` object that represents your storage account information.

trans-unit.source: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Use all of the previous code in front of the code in the following sections.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Use all of the previous code in front of the code in the following sections.

trans-unit.source: Get a `CloudBlobClient` object to reference an existing container in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Get a `CloudBlobClient` object to reference an existing container in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Some of the APIs that perform calls out to Azure Storage in ASP.NET 5 are asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Some of the APIs that perform calls out to Azure Storage in ASP.NET 5 are asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: See [Asynchronous Programming with Async and Await](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh191443.aspx) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Asynchronous Programming with Async and Await](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh191443.aspx) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Create a blob container in code
trans-unit.target: Create a blob container in code

trans-unit.source: You can also use the `CloudBlobClient` object to create a container in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the `CloudBlobClient` object to create a container in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: All you need to do is add a call to `CreateIfNotExistsAsync` to the above code as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: All you need to do is add a call to `CreateIfNotExistsAsync` to the above code as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Upload a blob into a container
trans-unit.target: Upload a blob into a container

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage supports block blobs and page blobs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage supports block blobs and page blobs.

trans-unit.source: In the majority of cases, block blob is the recommended type to use.
trans-unit.target: In the majority of cases, block blob is the recommended type to use.

trans-unit.source: To upload a file to a block blob, get a container reference and use it to get
trans-unit.target: To upload a file to a block blob, get a container reference and use it to get

trans-unit.source: a block blob reference.
trans-unit.target: a block blob reference.

trans-unit.source: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any
trans-unit.target: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any

trans-unit.source: stream of data to it by calling the `UploadFromStream` method.
trans-unit.target: stream of data to it by calling the `UploadFromStream` method.

trans-unit.source: This operation will create the blob if it didn't previously exist,
trans-unit.target: This operation will create the blob if it didn't previously exist,

trans-unit.source: or overwrite it if it does exist.
trans-unit.target: or overwrite it if it does exist.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.

trans-unit.source: List the blobs in a container
trans-unit.target: List the blobs in a container

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, use the `ListBlobs` method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, use the `ListBlobs` method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories

trans-unit.source: within it.
trans-unit.target: within it.

trans-unit.source: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a
trans-unit.target: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a

trans-unit.source: returned `IListBlobItem`, you must cast it to a `CloudBlockBlob`,
trans-unit.target: returned `IListBlobItem`, you must cast it to a `CloudBlockBlob`,

trans-unit.source: `CloudPageBlob`, or `CloudBlobDirectory` object.
trans-unit.target: `CloudPageBlob`, or `CloudBlobDirectory` object.

trans-unit.source: If the type is unknown, you can use a
trans-unit.target: If the type is unknown, you can use a

trans-unit.source: type check to determine which to cast it to.
trans-unit.target: type check to determine which to cast it to.

trans-unit.source: The following code
trans-unit.target: The following code

trans-unit.source: demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in
trans-unit.target: demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in

trans-unit.source: the `photos` container.
trans-unit.target: the `photos` container.

trans-unit.source: As shown in the previous example, the blob service has the concept of directories within containers, as
trans-unit.target: As shown in the previous example, the blob service has the concept of directories within containers, as

trans-unit.source: well.
trans-unit.target: well.

trans-unit.source: This is so that you can organize your blobs in a more folder-like
trans-unit.target: This is so that you can organize your blobs in a more folder-like

trans-unit.source: structure.
trans-unit.target: structure.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider the following set of block blobs in a container
trans-unit.target: For example, consider the following set of block blobs in a container

trans-unit.source: named `photos`.
trans-unit.target: named `photos`.

trans-unit.source: When you call `ListBlobs` on the 'photos' container (as shown in the previous example), the collection returned
trans-unit.target: When you call `ListBlobs` on the 'photos' container (as shown in the previous example), the collection returned

trans-unit.source: will contain `CloudBlobDirectory` and `CloudBlockBlob` objects
trans-unit.target: will contain `CloudBlobDirectory` and `CloudBlockBlob` objects

trans-unit.source: representing the directories and blobs contained at the top level.
trans-unit.target: representing the directories and blobs contained at the top level.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the resulting output.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the resulting output.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can set the `UseFlatBlobListing` parameter of of the `ListBlobs` method to
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can set the `UseFlatBlobListing` parameter of of the `ListBlobs` method to

trans-unit.source: `true`.
trans-unit.target: `true`.

trans-unit.source: This would result in every blob being returned as a `CloudBlockBlob`, regardless of directory.
trans-unit.target: This would result in every blob being returned as a `CloudBlockBlob`, regardless of directory.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the call to `ListBlobs`.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the call to `ListBlobs`.

trans-unit.target: And the next example shows the results.

trans-unit.source: Download blobs
trans-unit.target: Download blobs

trans-unit.source: To download blobs, use the `DownloadToStream` method.
trans-unit.target: To download blobs, use the `DownloadToStream` method.

trans-unit.source: The following
trans-unit.target: The following

trans-unit.source: example uses the `DownloadToStream` method to transfer the blob
trans-unit.target: example uses the `DownloadToStream` method to transfer the blob

trans-unit.source: contents to a stream object that you can then persist to a local file.
trans-unit.target: contents to a stream object that you can then persist to a local file.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the `DownloadToStream` method to download the contents of a blob as a text string.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the `DownloadToStream` method to download the contents of a blob as a text string.

trans-unit.source: Delete blobs
trans-unit.target: Delete blobs

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, use the `Delete` method.
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, use the `Delete` method.

trans-unit.source: List blobs in pages asynchronously
trans-unit.target: List blobs in pages asynchronously

trans-unit.source: If you are listing a large number of blobs, or you want to control the number of results you return in one listing operation, you can list blobs in pages of results.
trans-unit.target: If you are listing a large number of blobs, or you want to control the number of results you return in one listing operation, you can list blobs in pages of results.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to return results in pages asynchronously, so that execution is not blocked while waiting to return a large set of results.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to return results in pages asynchronously, so that execution is not blocked while waiting to return a large set of results.

trans-unit.source: This example shows a flat blob listing, but you can also perform a hierarchical listing, by setting the `useFlatBlobListing` parameter of the `ListBlobsSegmentedAsync` method to `false`.
trans-unit.target: This example shows a flat blob listing, but you can also perform a hierarchical listing, by setting the `useFlatBlobListing` parameter of the `ListBlobsSegmentedAsync` method to `false`.

trans-unit.source: Because the sample method calls an asynchronous method, it must be prefaced with the `async` keyword, and it must return a `Task` object.
trans-unit.target: Because the sample method calls an asynchronous method, it must be prefaced with the `async` keyword, and it must return a `Task` object.

trans-unit.source: The await keyword specified for the `ListBlobsSegmentedAsync` method suspends execution of the sample method until the listing task is complete.
trans-unit.target: The await keyword specified for the `ListBlobsSegmentedAsync` method suspends execution of the sample method until the listing task is complete.
